conclusion: Problem setup with dipole, charges, massless rod, XY-plane, center of mass at origin, uniform magnetic field perpendicular to XY-plane, initial conditions with dipole aligned with X-axis, initial angular velocity ω₀, center of mass velocity v⃗₀ = 0.
Each charge experiences a magnetic force F⃗ = q(v⃗ × B⃗).
Velocities of the two charges are v⃗₊ = ω₀ × r⃗₊ and v⃗₋ = ω₀ × r⃗₋.
Equation of motion for rotating dipole involves translational and rotational dynamics.
For dipole to reverse orientation, it must rotate at least 180° from initial position.
Dipole experiences torque causing precession and rotation due to initial angular velocity.
Initial angular velocity must overcome precession effect for dipole to reverse orientation.
Dipole's motion is combination of circular motion of center of mass and rotation around center of mass.
Moment of inertia for dipole is I = md²/2.
Magnetic force on each charge creates a torque τ = qdvB.
Torque at angle θ is τ = qdvB sinθ.
For minimum condition at θ = 180°, initial angular momentum must equal total change in angular momentum due to magnetic forces.
Minimum initial angular velocity calculated by setting Iω₀ = ∫₀ᵀ τ dt.
Minimum initial angular velocity ωₘᵢₙ = qBd/m.
Critical value where initial angular momentum allows dipole to complete 180° rotation against magnetic torque.
